Problem:
Consider a system governed by the heat equation \\(u_t = ku_{xx}\\), where \\(u\\) is the temperature distribution along a rod, and \\(k\\) is the thermal diffusivity constant. We investigate the effects of an initial heat distribution function \\(h(x)\\) and a later heat source intervention represented by \\(s(x, t)\\).

If an intervention using a new heat source \\(s(x, t)\\) is applied at time \\(t_1\\) affecting the temperature distribution, will the temperature distribution \\(u(x, T)\\) at time \\(T > t_1\\) depend solely on the initial distribution \\(h(x)\\) and not on the intervention \\(s(x, t)\\)?
Explanation: The introduction of an external heat source \\(s(x, t)\\) modifies the temperature distribution directly, where the influence of the source will propagate through time. Thus, the state at time \\(T > t_1\\) will depend on both the initial conditions and the characteristics and effects of the heat source intervention.
